Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>
>  
>
>>1) A tree based genome. This helps in a few different ways. When 
>>crossover occurs we only swap nodes that are co-located on both
>>
>Hi Colin...what does "co-located" mean if you are looking at two
>different trees?  Isn't there still a topology-matching problem
>with trees?  How do you know which branches match up?
>  
>
Hi Ken, well I don't do anything clever. My tree structure is N-ary and 
therefore a node's location can be specified by a list of numbers, each 
of which describes a traversal through the tree starting from the root. 
If two nodes have the same location path then I say they are co-located. 
In reality I don't use these paths I simply traverse both trees in 
parallel. Starting at the root I traverse (depth first, left to right) 
all children that both root nodes have in common, so if tree 1 has ten 
children and tree 2 has 5 then I only traverse the first five nodes of 
both trees. As traversal progresses I store the node pairs in a list, I 
can then select one or more of these node pairs and perform crossover.

Note that a single croosover could be considered to be analogous to 
traditional 2 point crossover. That is if we consider the trees 
flattened out and then note which nodes we have crossed over we see that 
the sub-tree we switched was in the middle of the genome. The three 
special cases are switching the root node (sort of pointless) highest 
leftmost/rightmost subtree - which switches the left and right parts of 
the genome repsectively - analogous to single point crossover.


>>of -1 means to traverse back up the tree one node. Reference nodes allow 
>>    
>>
>>for the possibility of re-use and therefore aid in evolving complexity.
>>    
>>
>
>Gruau's Cellular Encoding (CE) also uses a tree genome and can reuse
>nodes in the tree.  Have you looked at CE?  I describe it (and give a
>picture) in our Taxonomy for Artificial Embryogeny paper:
>
>http://steam.csres.utexas.edu/nn/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=121
>  
>
Yes I read the paper and it gave me a lot of ideas particularly with 
regards to modifying my own NE program. The cellular encoding described 
by Graua is more indirect than my own, e.g. the genome describes a path 
of development, splitting cells and creating connections at the current 
growth point - wherever that may be. I would say tha my genome is sort 
of halfway between that approach and the more 'brittle' (as you put it) 
direct encodings. In my own genome because each neuron's position is 
relative the the position of it's parent neuron it can make sense to 
copy branches of neurons and re-aatch them elsewhere - the same 
sub-structure of neurons will simply be built at a different location. 
Exactly the same occurs with my reference node as the sub-tree that is 
referred to takes it's base position as being the position in the tree 
traversal algorithm's 'current position' variable.

>The references to Gruau's original papers on CE are also given in that
>paper.  It might be interesting to see how your ideas are similar to
>Gruau's.
>  
>
Indeed. More generally though right now I'm trying to clarify in my head 
whether a complex development stage has any benefits over and above 
systems like my own (with some kind indirect encoding)- or whether the 
development phase seen in biology is purely a necessity of existing and 
trying to grow in the real, physical world with limited resources to 
hand. Having said that any system with indirect encoding has to go 
through some sort of development phase, e.g. in my own system the tree 
traversal algorithm that decodes the genome, follows the node references 
and builds the neural network is in effect a developmental stage.

At the same time I can see that a more indirect encoding might possibly 
support robustness in a genome encoding (canalization). This is were 
things get difficult, certainly the relative positioning in my own 
system gives us some sort of canalization as does my connection strategy 
(connect to the neuron closest to the end of the connection), but these 
are quite simple techniques and trying to envisage how greater levels of 
indirection would be beneficial is difficult.


For now I'm interested in implementing speciation and seeing what sort 
of impact it has. As in crossover I intend to compare the tree 
structures in order to generate a compatibility number with which to 
drive the speciation. This then should create a system very much like 
NEAT but with the ability to complexify - that's the theory anyhow :-)

Colin.
